questions.question: For a projectile launched from ground level with speed $v_0$ at angle $\theta$, which expressions give the initial velocity components?
questions.explanation: Horizontal component uses cosine, vertical component uses sine.

questions.question: In ideal angled projectile motion (no air resistance), which statement is correct about horizontal and vertical motions?
options: Horizontal motion has constant velocity, vertical motion has constant acceleration $-g$.
Horizontal motion has acceleration $+g$, vertical motion has zero acceleration.
questions.explanation: No horizontal force means constant horizontal velocity. Gravity gives constant downward acceleration.

questions.question: For a projectile launched from ground level with speed $v_0$ at angle $\theta$, what is the total time of flight until it returns to the same height?
At what launch angle (on level ground, fixed $v_0$) is the range of a projectile maximum?
Two projectiles are launched from level ground with the same speed $v_0$ at angles $\theta_1 = 30^\circ$ and $\theta_2 = 60^\circ$. Neglecting air resistance, how do their ranges compare?
For a projectile launched from ground level with speed $v_0$ at angle $\theta$, which expression gives the maximum height above the launch point?
Which of the following is the correct range formula on level ground (launch and landing at same height)?
A projectile is launched from ground level and lands back at the same level. Which statement about symmetry is true?
options: The time going up is greater than the time coming down.
The time going up is less than the time coming down.
The time to reach maximum height equals the time to fall back to launch level.
There is no symmetry in time.
questions.explanation: Projectile motion is symmetric about the apex, so time up = time down.

questions.question: At a certain height below the apex, a projectile has speed 18 m/s while moving upward. Neglecting air resistance, what will be its speed at that same height on the way down?
questions.explanation: Due to symmetry, speed depends only on height, so it will be the same 18 m/s on the way down.

questions.question: At the highest point of its trajectory (same-height launch and landing), which statement about the projectile's velocity is correct?
options: Both horizontal and vertical components are zero.
Horizontal component is zero; vertical component is nonzero.
Vertical component is zero; horizontal component is nonzero.
Both components are nonzero and equal.
questions.explanation: At the apex, vertical velocity is zero, but horizontal velocity remains constant and nonzero.
